channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Addendum: Human alteration of global surface water storage variability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06165-7

Addendum: Human alteration of global surface water storage variability
item.dc:title: Addendum: Human alteration of global surface water storage variability
item.dc:creator: Sarah W. Cooley
Jonathan C. Ryan
Laurence C. Smith

item.title: How I use science to protect my people’s birthright
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01941-x

Jean-Luc Kanapé combines the ancestral knowledge of his Indigenous Canadian community, the Innu, with technology to protect the region’s caribou from predators and environmental damage.
item.dc:title: How I use science to protect my people’s birthright
item.dc:creator: Patricia Maia Noronha

item.title: Violence towards women in environmental protests
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01885-2

An analysis unpicks the various forms of violence that women face when they stand up to polluters and natural-resource extractors.
item.dc:title: Violence towards women in environmental protests
item.dc:creator: Abigail Klopper

item.title: Landmark ‘kids’ climate trial begins: how science will take the stand
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01931-z

US youths are taking the state of Montana to court for supporting the fossil-fuel industry rather than protecting the environment and their health.
item.dc:title: Landmark ‘kids’ climate trial begins: how science will take the stand
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero
Jeff Tollefson

item.title: A family affair: how scientist parents’ career paths can influence children’s choices
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01939-5

Early exposure to science inspired four researchers to pursue research careers.
item.dc:title: A family affair: how scientist parents’ career paths can influence children’s choices
item.dc:creator: Andy Tay

item.title: Tackling pervasive sexism in Australian science requires money, leadership and time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 12 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01925-x

Lessons in advancing gender equity in research from my time in the United States at Lamont–Doherty Earth Observatory and in Australia.
item.dc:title: Tackling pervasive sexism in Australian science requires money, leadership and time
item.dc:creator: Robin Bell

item.title: Author Correction: RNA conformational propensities determine cellular activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06286-z

Author Correction: RNA conformational propensities determine cellular activity
item.dc:title: Author Correction: RNA conformational propensities determine cellular activity

item.title: Neurotech DIY: fixing your own implant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01940-y

As the neurotechnology market expands, what happens to those left behind?
item.dc:title: Neurotech DIY: fixing your own implant
item.dc:creator: Dan Fox

item.title: How to prebunk misinformation, and the daredevil of the Nile: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01923-z

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: How to prebunk misinformation, and the daredevil of the Nile: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: Taurine supplement makes animals live longer — what it means for people is unclear
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01910-4

The energy-drink ingredient offers striking health benefits in mice, monkeys and worms. But more work is needed to investigate its link with ageing.
item.dc:title: Taurine supplement makes animals live longer — what it means for people is unclear
item.dc:creator: Myriam Vidal Valero

item.title: Have a high-pitched voice? It might be in your genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01901-5

Survey of nearly 13,000 Icelanders pinpoints for the first time a genetic variant that shapes whether a person’s voice sounds high.
item.dc:title: Have a high-pitched voice? It might be in your genes
item.dc:creator: Freda Kreier

item.title: NIH to intensify scrutiny of foreign grant recipients in wake of COVID origins debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01930-0

Researchers speak out over US biomedical agency’s new funding policy.
item.dc:title: NIH to intensify scrutiny of foreign grant recipients in wake of COVID origins debate
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Ukraine dam collapse: what scientists are watching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01928-8

Extensive flooding could have severe consequences for farming, health and the environment.
item.dc:title: Ukraine dam collapse: what scientists are watching
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Why are the Canadian wildfires so bad this year?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01902-4

Hot, dry weather and human carelessness have led to a huge burnt area — and to a choking haze that is affecting millions of people.
item.dc:title: Why are the Canadian wildfires so bad this year?
item.dc:creator: Brian Owens

item.title: All-perovskite tandem solar cells with 3D/3D bilayer perovskite heterojunction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06278-z

All-perovskite tandem solar cells with 3D/3D bilayer perovskite heterojunction
item.dc:title: All-perovskite tandem solar cells with 3D/3D bilayer perovskite heterojunction

item.title: Cholera bacteria turn slime into an offensive weapon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01860-x

Goopy ‘biofilms’ normally serve as a protective shield, but Vibrio cholerae uses them to kill immune cells.
item.dc:title: Cholera bacteria turn slime into an offensive weapon

item.title: Revealed: the millions of dollars in time wasted making papers fit journal guidelines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01846-9

The high cost of ‘reformatting’ prompts a call for journals to change their requirements.
item.dc:title: Revealed: the millions of dollars in time wasted making papers fit journal guidelines
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Daily briefing: We’re just as kind and honest as ever
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01917-x

Decades of data show the widespread belief that morality is waning is an illusion. Plus, the first images of the tallest tree in the Amazon and a ‘lost world’ of previously unknown microorganisms that once dominated complex life on Earth.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: We’re just as kind and honest as ever
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Powerful microscope captures motor proteins in unprecedented detail
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01906-0

Called MINFLUX, the super-resolution method allows researchers to track molecules under cellular conditions.
item.dc:title: Powerful microscope captures motor proteins in unprecedented detail
item.dc:creator: Amanda Heidt

item.title: Cryo-EM structure of SARS-CoV-2 postfusion spike in membrane
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06273-4

Cryo-EM structure of SARS-CoV-2 postfusion spike in membrane
item.dc:title: Cryo-EM structure of SARS-CoV-2 postfusion spike in membrane

item.title: Baby whales wither away under avian attack
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01858-5

After gulls switched their focus from southern right whale mothers to calves, scientists recorded a drop in calf survival.
item.dc:title: Baby whales wither away under avian attack

item.title: Are you a postdoc working in academia or industry? Share your career experiences with Nature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01877-2

Our second global survey of postdoctoral researchers is now live, with new questions to reflect seismic changes to the world of work since 2020.
item.dc:title: Are you a postdoc working in academia or industry? Share your career experiences with Nature
item.dc:creator: David Payne

item.title: Joyous ode by Beethoven flows from a robot’s fingers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01859-4

Digits made of soft materials tap out a melody from the composer’s Ninth Symphony on a keyboard.
item.dc:title: Joyous ode by Beethoven flows from a robot’s fingers

item.title: Why Nature will not allow the use of generative AI in images and video
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01546-4

Saying ‘no’ to this kind of visual content is a question of research integrity, consent, privacy and intellectual-property protection.
item.dc:title: Why Nature will not allow the use of generative AI in images and video

item.title: A brain circuit for infanticide, in mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01895-0

Research reveals system underlying behaviour change towards young, and identifying the source of fast solar wind.
item.dc:title: A brain circuit for infanticide, in mice
item.dc:creator: Noah Baker
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: The battle against tobacco is not yet won
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01836-x

Efforts to discourage new smokers and help people to quit are bringing smoking rates down in many places, but it’s going to take more to put an end to tobacco smoking altogether.
item.dc:title: The battle against tobacco is not yet won
item.dc:creator: Richard Hodson

item.title: Reply to: Ptbp1 deletion does not induce astrocyte-to-neuron conversion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06067-8

Reply to: Ptbp1 deletion does not induce astrocyte-to-neuron conversion
item.dc:title: Reply to: Ptbp1 deletion does not induce astrocyte-to-neuron conversion
item.dc:creator: Yajing Hao
Jing Hu
Yuanchao Xue
Steven F. Dowdy

Xiang-Dong Fu

item.title: A metal-poor star with abundances from a pair-instability supernova
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06028-1

The chemical composition of the Galactic halo star J1010+2358 shows extremely low sodium and cobalt abundances, different from most other halo stars, indicative of a very metal-poor star being seeded with elements from a pair-instability supernova.
item.dc:title: A metal-poor star with abundances from a pair-instability supernova
item.dc:creator: Qian-Fan Xing
Gang Zhao
Zheng-Wei Liu
Alexander Heger
Zhan-Wen Han
Wako Aoki
Yu-Qin Chen
Miho N. Ishigaki
Hai-Ning Li
Jing-Kun Zhao

item.title: Chiral phonons in quartz probed by X-rays
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06016-5

Our experimental proof of chiral phonons demonstrates a degree of freedom in condensed matter that is of fundamental importance and opens the door to exploration of emergent phenomena based on chiral bosons.
item.dc:title: Chiral phonons in quartz probed by X-rays
item.dc:creator: Hiroki Ueda
Mirian García-Fernández

Ptbp1 deletion does not induce astrocyte-to-neuron conversion

Sika Zheng

Seth Blackshaw

item.title: Northwest African Neolithic initiated by migrants from Iberia and Levant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06166-6

Genome sequencing of nine individuals shows ancestry shifts in the Neolithization of northwestern Africa that probably mirrored a heterogeneous economic and cultural landscape in a more multifaceted process than observed in other regions.
item.dc:title: Northwest African Neolithic initiated by migrants from Iberia and Levant
item.dc:creator: Luciana G. Simões
Torsten Günther
Rafael M. Martínez-Sánchez

Mattias Jakobsson

item.title: Organic–inorganic covalent–ionic molecules for elastic ceramic plastic
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06117-1

Covalent organic molecules can be combined with ionic inorganic molecules to create a hybrid material demonstrating paradoxical mechanical properties in a bottom-up manner, enabling the manufacture of an ‘elastic ceramic plastic’.
item.dc:title: Organic–inorganic covalent–ionic molecules for elastic ceramic plastic
item.dc:creator: Weifeng Fang
Zhao Mu
Yan He
Kangren Kong
Kai Jiang
Ruikang Tang
Zhaoming Liu

item.title: Class B1 GPCR activation by an intracellular agonist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06169-3

A new intracellular agonist-binding pocket is identified that is common to many G protein-coupled receptors, which will have implications for the development of biased compounds that target this large group of receptors.
item.dc:title: Class B1 GPCR activation by an intracellular agonist
item.dc:creator: Kazuhiro Kobayashi
Kouki Kawakami
Tsukasa Kusakizako
Atsuhiro Tomita
Michihiro Nishimura

Osamu Nureki

item.title: Heritable transcriptional defects from aberrations of nuclear architecture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06157-7

Micronuclei, which are common features of nuclei in cancer cells, can generate heritable sources of transcriptional suppression, a finding that establishes an inherent relationship between chromosomal instability and variation in chromatin state and gene expression.
item.dc:title: Heritable transcriptional defects from aberrations of nuclear architecture
item.dc:creator: Stamatis Papathanasiou
Nikos A. Mynhier
Shiwei Liu
Gregory Brunette
Ema Stokasimov

David Pellman

item.title: Major southern San Andreas earthquakes modulated by lake-filling events
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06058-9

Analysis of new geologic and palaeoseismic data using a 3D finite-element model suggests that the past six major earthquakes on the southern San Andreas Fault were probably triggered by highstands of ancient Lake Cahuilla.
item.dc:title: Major southern San Andreas earthquakes modulated by lake-filling events
item.dc:creator: Ryley G. Hill
Matthew Weingarten
Thomas K. Rockwell
Yuri Fialko

item.title: Dendrite initiation and propagation in lithium metal solid-state batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05970-4

Analysis of dendrite initiation, owing to filling of pores with lithium by means of microcracks, and propagation, caused by wedge opening, shows that there are two separate processes during dendrite failure of lithium metal solid-state batteries.
item.dc:title: Dendrite initiation and propagation in lithium metal solid-state batteries
item.dc:creator: Ziyang Ning

item.title: Epigenetic dysregulation from chromosomal transit in micronuclei
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06084-7

Missegregated chromosomes that are sequestrated in micronuclei are subject to changes in histone modifications leading to abnormalities in chromatin accessibility that remain long after the chromosomes have been reincorporated into the primary nucleus.
item.dc:title: Epigenetic dysregulation from chromosomal transit in micronuclei
item.dc:creator: Albert S. Agustinus

item.title: Faster sorting algorithms discovered using deep reinforcement learning
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06004-9

Artificial intelligence goes beyond the current state of the art by discovering unknown, faster sorting algorithms as a single-player game using a deep reinforcement learning agent. These algorithms are now used in the standard C++ sort library.
item.dc:title: Faster sorting algorithms discovered using deep reinforcement learning
item.dc:creator: Daniel J. Mankowitz

item.title: Structural basis for FGF hormone signalling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06155-9

This study reveals how Klotho and heparan sulfate glycosaminoglycan coreceptors enable FGF hormones to induce asymmetric 1:2 FGF–FGFR dimerization mandatory for FGFR kinase activation and hence signalling.
item.dc:title: Structural basis for FGF hormone signalling
item.dc:creator: Lingfeng Chen
Lili Fu

item.title: Tumour immune rejection triggered by activation of α2-adrenergic receptors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06110-8

Agonists of α2-adrenergic receptors could substantially improve the clinical efficacy of cancer immunotherapy.
item.dc:title: Tumour immune rejection triggered by activation of α2-adrenergic receptors
item.dc:creator: Jingjing Zhu
Stefan Naulaerts
Loubna Boudhan
Manon Martin
Laurent Gatto
Benoit J. Van den Eynde

item.title: Outer membrane utilisomes mediate glycan uptake in gut Bacteroidetes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06146-w

A structural and functional analysis of the systems involved in oligosaccharide uptake in gut Bacteroidetes describes multicomponent complexes termed utilisomes that include pre-processing and transport subunits.
item.dc:title: Outer membrane utilisomes mediate glycan uptake in gut Bacteroidetes
item.dc:creator: Joshua B. R. White

item.title: Health system-scale language models are all-purpose prediction engines
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06160-y

A clinical language model trained on unstructured clinical notes from the electronic health record enhances prediction of clinical and operational events.
item.dc:title: Health system-scale language models are all-purpose prediction engines
item.dc:creator: Lavender Yao Jiang

item.title: The illusion of moral decline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06137-x

We show that the perception of moral decline is pervasive, perdurable, unfounded and easily produced, and suggest that this illusion has implications for research on the misallocation of scarce resources, the underuse of social support and social influence.
item.dc:title: The illusion of moral decline
item.dc:creator: Adam M. Mastroianni
Daniel T. Gilbert

item.title: Interchange reconnection as the source of the fast solar wind within coronal holes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05955-3

Measurements of fast solar wind streams from the Parker Solar Probe spacecraft provide strong evidence for the interchange reconnection mechanism being responsible for accelerating the fast solar wind.
item.dc:title: Interchange reconnection as the source of the fast solar wind within coronal holes
item.dc:creator: S. D. Bale
J. F. Drake

item.title: Hydration solids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06144-y

A study shows that water can control macroscopic properties of biological materials through the hydration force, giving rise to a distinct class of solid matter with unusual properties.
item.dc:title: Hydration solids
item.dc:creator: Steven G. Harrellson
Michael S. DeLay
Xi Chen
Ahmet-Hamdi Cavusoglu
Jonathan Dworkin
Howard A. Stone
Ozgur Sahin

item.title: A cytosolic surveillance mechanism activates the mitochondrial UPR
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06142-0

We identify a highly controlled cytosolic surveillance mechanism that integrates independent mitochondrial stress signals to initiate the mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPR), revealing a link between mitochondrial and cytosolic proteostasis.
item.dc:title: A cytosolic surveillance mechanism activates the mitochondrial UPR
item.dc:creator: F. X. Reymond Sutandy
Ines Gößner
Georg Tascher
Christian Münch

item.title: Lost world of complex life and the late rise of the eukaryotic crown
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06170-w

Analysis of sedimentary rocks from the mid-Proterozoic interval reveals traces of protosteroids, suggesting the widespread presence of stem-group eukaryotes that predated and co-existed with the crown-group ancestors of modern eukaryotes.
item.dc:title: Lost world of complex life and the late rise of the eukaryotic crown
item.dc:creator: Jochen J. Brocks
Benjamin J. Nettersheim
Pierre Adam
Philippe Schaeffer

Tharika Liyanage
Lennart M. van Maldegem
Christian Hallmann
Janet M. Hope

item.title: Ultraviolet radiation shapes dendritic cell leukaemia transformation in the skin
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06156-8

Blastic plasmacytoid dendritic cell neoplasm (BPDCN) arises from clonal (premalignant) haematopoietic precursors in the bone marrow, and BPDCN skin tumours first develop at sun-exposed anatomical sites and are distinguished by clonally expanded mutations induced by ultraviolet radiation.
item.dc:title: Ultraviolet radiation shapes dendritic cell leukaemia transformation in the skin
item.dc:creator: Gabriel K. Griffin

item.title: Life history complementarity and the maintenance of biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06154-w

Ecological models of species with diverse life history traits show that complementary combinations of life history strategy contribute, together with fitness and niche differences, to the maintenance of biodiversity.
item.dc:title: Life history complementarity and the maintenance of biodiversity
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Jops
James P. O’Dwyer

item.title: Unveiling the transition from niche to dispersal assembly in ecology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06161-x

This study shows through a field experiment that tropical intertidal communities switch from a niche- to a dispersal-assembled regime as immigration rates rise.
item.dc:title: Unveiling the transition from niche to dispersal assembly in ecology
item.dc:creator: Lynette H. L. Loke
Ryan A. Chisholm

item.title: Antagonistic circuits mediating infanticide and maternal care in female mice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06147-9

ESR1-expressing cells in the principal nucleus of the bed nucleus of stria terminalis are necessary, sufficient and naturally activated during infanticide, and they form reciprocal inhibition with the maternal cells to control young-directed behaviours in female mice.
item.dc:title: Antagonistic circuits mediating infanticide and maternal care in female mice
item.dc:creator: Long Mei
Rongzhen Yan
Luping Yin
Regina M. Sullivan
Dayu Lin

item.title: How screenwriting can help your grant writing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01881-6

What recent film riveted you? What if your next grant proposal engaged reviewers as effectively as that film grabbed you?
item.dc:title: How screenwriting can help your grant writing
item.dc:creator: Christine W. Hartmann

item.title: Brain-zapping technology helps smokers to quit
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01839-8

Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation is already approved to help people overcome addiction to cigarettes, but researchers still have a lot to learn about how to deliver the treatment effectively.
item.dc:title: Brain-zapping technology helps smokers to quit
item.dc:creator: Simon Makin

item.title: Lithium filaments wedge open cracks in solid-state batteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01813-4

The development of a promising type of battery has been plagued by an issue that causes these devices to fail — lithium filaments grow in the electrolyte. An investigation of this failure mechanism could help to solve the problem.
item.dc:title: Lithium filaments wedge open cracks in solid-state batteries
item.dc:creator: Kelsey B. Hatzell
Maha Yusuf

item.title: Smoking: an avoidable health disaster explained
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01837-w

Statistics show that, despite some progress towards smoking cessation, tobacco continues to place an extraordinarily heavy burden on global health.
item.dc:title: Smoking: an avoidable health disaster explained
item.dc:creator: Richard Hodson

item.title: China’s rolling COVID waves could hit every six months — infecting millions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01872-7

The latest surge is unlikely to crash the country’s health-care system, but scientists fear hundreds of millions of infections.
item.dc:title: China’s rolling COVID waves could hit every six months — infecting millions
item.dc:creator: Yvaine Ye

item.title: Infancy of sterol biosynthesis hints at extinct eukaryotic species
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01816-1

A newly discovered fossil record of steroid molecules, spanning 1.64 billion years, points to ancient organisms in the eukaryotic domain being capable of only early steps in the synthesis of sterol molecules.
item.dc:title: Infancy of sterol biosynthesis hints at extinct eukaryotic species
item.dc:creator: Fabien Kenig

item.title: Finding the Amazon’s tallest trees — an epic quest to reach hidden giants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01828-x

When researchers spotted clues that trees were growing to record heights in the rainforest, they tried, failed and tried again to reach the remote site.
item.dc:title: Finding the Amazon’s tallest trees — an epic quest to reach hidden giants
item.dc:creator: Richard Monastersky

item.title: The surprising benefit of meditative walks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01894-1

When astrobiologist Erin Gibbons is stuck on a problem, she sometimes finds it best to just walk away.
item.dc:title: The surprising benefit of meditative walks
item.dc:creator: Erin Gibbons

item.title: Don’t feed the physicists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01835-y

Universal standards.
item.dc:title: Don’t feed the physicists
item.dc:creator: Alex Small

item.title: What it means to practise values-based research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01878-1

Environmental scientist Max Liboiron ties principles of humility and accountability to research that respects people and their relationship with the land.
item.dc:title: What it means to practise values-based research
item.dc:creator: Spoorthy Raman

item.title: Deaths of African cheetahs in India shine spotlight on controversial conservation project
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01861-w

Scientists fear that an Indian park is not enough space for the planned population — and that not enough work has been done with locals on how they will respond to the animals.
item.dc:title: Deaths of African cheetahs in India shine spotlight on controversial conservation project
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: A ‘lost world’ of early microbes thrived one billion years ago
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01847-8

Fat-like compounds in ancient rocks point to a vast array of previously unknown microorganisms that once dominated complex life on Earth.
item.dc:title: A ‘lost world’ of early microbes thrived one billion years ago
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: Is nicotine bad for long-term health? Scientists aren’t sure yet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01840-1

As e-cigarettes grow in popularity, the lack of knowledge about whether nicotine contributes to the damaging health effects of smoking is becoming more worrying.
item.dc:title: Is nicotine bad for long-term health? Scientists aren’t sure yet
item.dc:creator: Anthony King

item.title: Daily briefing: Shingles jab might cut the risk of dementia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01904-2

Hints that vaccination against shingles might lower the risk of dementia by 20%. Plus, COVID waves could hit China every six months and cheetah deaths in India shine a spotlight on a controversial conservation project.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Shingles jab might cut the risk of dementia
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: African countries fight for tobacco control
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01838-9

A lack of resources and interference from the tobacco industry make it difficult to strengthen anti-smoking regulations.
item.dc:title: African countries fight for tobacco control
item.dc:creator: Tammy Worth

item.title: AI learns to write sorting software on its own
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01812-5

Deep reinforcement learning has been used to improve computer code by treating the task as a game — with no special knowledge needed on the part of the player. The result has already worked its way into countless programs.
item.dc:title: AI learns to write sorting software on its own
item.dc:creator: Armando Solar-Lezama

item.title: DeepMind AI creates algorithms that sort data faster than those built by people
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01883-4

The technology developed by DeepMind that plays Go and chess can also help to write code.
item.dc:title: DeepMind AI creates algorithms that sort data faster than those built by people
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hutson

item.title: Elastic ceramic plastic made using molecules with organic and inorganic parts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01784-6

Hybrid molecules containing organic and inorganic components were assembled through bottom-up synthesis into a continuous network of interpenetrating molecular-scale organic and inorganic ionic domains. The resulting material, called elastic ceramic plastic, shows ceramic-like hardness and strength, rubber-like deformability and resilience, and plastic-like mouldability.
item.dc:title: Elastic ceramic plastic made using molecules with organic and inorganic parts

item.title: A battle between neural circuits for infanticide and maternal-care behaviours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01513-z

A previously unknown neural circuit in the brains of female mice is activated during infanticidal behaviour, and reciprocally inhibits another circuit that promotes maternal-care behaviour. These circuits show opposing changes in excitability when female mice become mothers, explaining the switch in young-directed behaviours that occurs with motherhood.
item.dc:title: A battle between neural circuits for infanticide and maternal-care behaviours

item.title: Ultraviolet light shapes the evolution of precancerous cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01815-2

Much remains to be discovered about how premalignant cells become cancer cells. An analysis of the development of a type of human leukaemia implicates ultraviolet light in triggering a rare form of cancer.
item.dc:title: Ultraviolet light shapes the evolution of precancerous cells
item.dc:creator: Elli Papaemmanuil

item.title: Morality is declining, right? Scientists say that idea is an illusion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01848-7

Surveys show people around the world have believed for decades that morals are decaying — but other survey data contradict that perception.
item.dc:title: Morality is declining, right? Scientists say that idea is an illusion
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Ancient DNA reveals how farming spread into northwest Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01768-6

Genomic data from bones and teeth found at archaeological sites across Morocco paint a picture of how Neolithic farmers and pastoralists spread into northwest Africa that is more complex than previously thought.
item.dc:title: Ancient DNA reveals how farming spread into northwest Africa
item.dc:creator: Louise Humphrey
Abdeljalil Bouzouggar

item.title: What maintains biodiversity in ecological communities?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01669-8

An experiment testing two opposing theories about how biodiversity is governed in communities was done at seawall structures at the boundary between high and low tides. Rather than the conventional model, the results support one that suggests that immigration has a larger role in maintaining diversity than do niches.
item.dc:title: What maintains biodiversity in ecological communities?

item.title: Publisher Correction: Cortico-cortical feedback engages active dendrites in visual cortex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06241-y

Publisher Correction: Cortico-cortical feedback engages active dendrites in visual cortex
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Cortico-cortical feedback engages active dendrites in visual cortex
item.dc:creator: Mehmet Fişek
Dustin Herrmann
Alexander Egea-Weiss
Matilda Cloves
Lisa Bauer
